instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B  that has no backlight, and it's breaking all the F9700 fuses.
When I lift up the fuse, I don't see any short on the pads, but when I replace the fuse, it burns again.
Already tried with 2 LCDs.
What shall i do from here? Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at both sides of <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.
Also check if <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is not already shorted S-D.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message:
<DIODE>D9701</DIODE>:
W/O LCD:
1 = 0.450
2 = 0V shorted but diode looks good (only passes voltages from one direction).

<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> seams to be ok.

This is a 50V line. What voltage should I inject to figure out where the short is, or is there a better approuch?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message:
Why to inject voltage?
There are only 4 caps and <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>.
Very likely the chip is bad.
Inspect LCD connector too, just in case.

However, for pure short, 1-2V should be sufficient to heat the culprit.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message:
Hi,
After replacing <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>, LCD connector, <CAPACITOR>C9796</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9020</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9799</CAPACITOR>, turn out to be <CAPACITOR>C9797</CAPACITOR> :-). It gave a fight, but it turn out to be a success!
Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B backlight
threads.message: You should start removing the caps...
